citations.narrative:
Damage to the small gauge wire added to the bottom section of three primary enclosures housing rabbits, created several
sharp points protruding into each enclosure within the rabbits' reach. Sharp points such as these that extend into animal
enclosures can cause injury. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained in good repair to protect the rabbits
from injury.
Correct by: 01/22/2026.

The following deficiencies were identified with the facility’s perimeter fence at the zoo:
• At the African Crested porcupine’s primary enclosure facing the guest parking lot, both the left and right corner of the six-
foot perimeter fence was not three feet away from the primary enclosure. Instead, it was only 16 inches away at the right
corner and the left corner was continuous with the perimeter fence.
• At the creek between the entrance to the zoo from the parking lot and the barnyard exhibition, the fence serving as the
perimeter fence for all animals in the zoo, at the level of the creek closer to the barnyard exhibit, had no wire present in
one area so a large gap approximately one foot wide by 2 feet tall was identified.
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t an
adequate secondary containment system to hold animals that may escape their primary enclosures or a sufficient barrier
to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. The facility must ensure they maintain in good repair a continuous 8-foot-
high perimeter fencing for dangerous animals and 6-foot-high fencing for non-dangerous animals (porcupines). Such
fences must be at least 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure for animals housed outdoors.
Correct by: 02/28/2026.

In the aviary housing budgies and golden pheasants, a live electrical cord was unprotected and accessible to the birds.
The unprotected electrical cord for a heater inside the large shelter box was secured from the top of the box to the fencing
located behind it, spanning a distance of approximately 3 feet, eventually coming out to the side of the wire enclosure.
Electrical cords pose a significant health risk to animals that may peck or perch on them. Primary enclosures must be
constructed and maintained so that they protect the birds from injury.
Correct by: 01/22/2026.

Three geese, housed outdoors within the drive-thru, did not have an adequately sized pool or other aquatic area provided
that allows each bird to conduct normal waterfowl behaviors, such as swimming, submarining, and/or foraging. Instead,
they have access to one area for water (an oval livestock tub) that was approximately 4 feet long by 2 1/2 feet wide and
12 inches tall. Additionally, there was only about 6 to 8 inches of water provided within it which was not deep enough for
the geese to swim or to submarine. Failure to provide a pool or other aquatic area of sufficient surface area and depth, for
all aquatic birds in the enclosure to be able to express natural behaviors, can lead to increased stress and a decline in
physical condition. Primary enclosures housing wading and/or aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area and
a dry area that allows easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic areas must be of
sufficient surface area and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion,
bathing, swimming and foraging.
Correct by: 02/15/2026.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
STEPHANIE MAYARD, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.53(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Damage to the small gauge wire added to the bottom section of three primary enclosures housing rabbits, created several 
sharp points protruding into each enclosure within the rabbits' reach. Sharp points such as these that extend into animal 
enclosures can cause injury. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained in good repair to protect the rabbits 
from injury.  
Correct by: 01/22/2026. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The following deficiencies were identified with the facility’s perimeter fence at the zoo: 
• At the African Crested porcupine’s primary enclosure facing the guest parking lot, both the left and right corner of the six-
foot perimeter fence was not three feet away from the primary enclosure. Instead, it was only 16 inches away at the right 
corner and the left corner was continuous with the perimeter fence.  
• At the creek between the entrance to the zoo from the parking lot and the barnyard exhibition, the fence serving as the 
perimeter fence for all animals in the zoo, at the level of the creek closer to the barnyard exhibit, had no wire present in 
one area so a large gap approximately one foot wide by 2 feet tall was identified.  
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t an 
adequate secondary containment system to hold animals that may escape their primary enclosures or a sufficient barrier 
to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. The facility must ensure they maintain in good repair a continuous 8-foot-
high perimeter fencing for dangerous animals and 6-foot-high fencing for non-dangerous animals (porcupines). Such 
fences must be at least 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure for animals housed outdoors. 
Correct by: 02/28/2026. 
3.153(a)(1)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
In the aviary housing budgies and golden pheasants, a live electrical cord was unprotected and accessible to the birds. 
The unprotected electrical cord for a heater inside the large shelter box was secured from the top of the box to the fencing 
located behind it, spanning a distance of approximately 3 feet, eventually coming out to the side of the wire enclosure. 
Electrical cords pose a significant health risk to animals that may peck or perch on them. Primary enclosures must be

constructed and maintained so that they protect the birds from injury.  
Correct by: 01/22/2026. 
3.153(c) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Three geese, housed outdoors within the drive-thru, did not have an adequately sized pool or other aquatic area provided 
that allows each bird to conduct normal waterfowl behaviors, such as swimming, submarining, and/or foraging. Instead, 
they have access to one area for water (an oval livestock tub) that was approximately 4 feet long by 2 1/2 feet wide and 
12 inches tall. Additionally, there was only about 6 to 8 inches of water provided within it which was not deep enough for 
the geese to swim or to submarine. Failure to provide a pool or other aquatic area of sufficient surface area and depth, for 
all aquatic birds in the enclosure to be able to express natural behaviors, can lead to increased stress and a decline in 
physical condition. Primary enclosures housing wading and/or aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area and 
a dry area that allows easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic areas must be of 
sufficient surface area and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion, 
bathing, swimming and foraging.  
Correct by: 02/15/2026. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
STEPHANIE MAYARD, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
